Title.evidence: Title: Single Ventricle Reconstruction Trial: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either a modified Blalock-Taussig shunt or a right ventricle-to-pulmonary artery shunt.

Participants.evidence: This randomised controlled trial included 393 participants with single right ventricle lesions, recruited from multiple centers.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either a modified Blalock-Taussig shunt or a right ventricle-to-pulmonary artery shunt.

Objective.evidence: The Single Ventricle Reconstruction trial aimed to compare outcomes of two shunt types in patients with single right ventricle lesions undergoing the Norwood procedure.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was hospital length of stay (LOS) at the stage II procedure, measured in days.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was conducted using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment ensured by sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not applicable due to the nature of the intervention.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 393 participants were randomised, with 196 receiving the modified Blalock-Taussig shunt and 197 receiving the right ventricle-to-pulmonary artery shunt.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The median stage II procedure hospital LOS was 8 days (IQR 6, 14), with no significant difference between shunt types.

Harms.evidence: Hospital mortality was 4.3%, and transplantation occurred in 0.8% of cases.
